title: the perfect and free tracker for all your needs
content:
after seeing an ad for macro factor, probably the most used tracking app currently and seeing that it requires a subscription fee, i just had to write a review to defend and support my biggest help in every day life for the last 2 years, mynetdiary. 

mynetdiary is able to help you count calories, gain weight, lose weight, keep track of everything you eat by scanning the barcode of your food or looking it up, and in 9/10 cases, what you're looking for is part of their system and there is accurate information on it. 

mynetdiary can give you an accurate calorie count for your goals simply based on the info you put in. you log your weight, set a goal weight, and choose the weekly rate to gain or lose weight and it does the math for you, giving you your daily calorie limit and as you continue to log your changing weight, it will automatically update your calories to continue furthering your progress. 

mynetdiary doesn't track steps and doesnt have a gps system like pacer does, which is a great app to use along side this one for tracking everything that you need to. 
the app does however have a section on the dashboard for logging steps, logging exercise (this is where it accounts for calories burned) and even allows you to track your water consumption which can help remind you to stay hydrated. 

i was told about mynetdiary by a friend in june 2023 and since then have gained 45 lbs and at least half of that was muscle (i was a novice at the time, so it wasnt newbie gains). 
mynetdiary has helped me with all of my goals and has allowed me to become a completely different person physically, all without paying for a subscription! 

i hope that the developers of mynetdiary continue to keep it's basic options and functions free for people like me and take pride in the versatility of their work and the integrity of their support through making this app.

title: bad for women
content: i am a female endurance athlete trying to improve my fitness after an injury/hiatus led to gaining 20 lbs. i paid for the "advanced autopilot" to estimate my calories. at first, it seemed like a great tool to lose weight at a healthy rate. however, the moment i put on a bit of pms water weight, advanced autopilot started insisting i should eat barely over 1,200 per day as my baseline calories--a stupid and dangerous recommendation. following this advice would have not only been miserable, it would have harmed my health and athleticism. there was no way to account for pms in the algorithm. it would not be hard for any data scientist to make a simple model to account for that. also, i don't want to figure it out on my own--i thought the whole point of the app is to choose my calorie budget. in addition to this shortcoming, the differences in calorie estimates for male/female are also harmful. the most recent research has actually shown men's and women's metabolisms are not fundamentally different if muscle mass/fat ratios are equal. while it's true most women have more fat and less muscle than most men, this varies so much on an individual basis. i don't get why the so-called "advanced autopilot" can't just figure out my baseline metabolism without gender-based assumptions. i can put that i am "active," but a male who is "active" still gets recommended more calories. overall, i feel this app is only aimed at sedentary people who want to be "skinny." if you are a woman and actually want to be healthy, tread with extreme caution!
